body:
This is a side effect of #1051 where this behavior was insisted upon by another ARM user. As a non-ARM user, I gotta say your architecture is a huge pain in the ass. ;)

(Next auto upgrade will break things again, unless this is fixed. Disable auto upgrades for the time being as a workaround.)

I know, ARM is a mess. However, I do not understand #1051 really, so my simple view of things is that the upgrade should stick to the build that was previously installed. If a x86-64 user decided to run the x86(-32) version (which should work because the 64 bit kernel also executes 32 bit binaries) then auto-upgrade should not force the 64 bit version. Or is this something different?

The thing with that ticket is that previously the syncthing build system required explicitly specifying armv5 armv6 or armv7 as the architecture to build for, and then we know exactly what to upgrade to as well. But if you're _on_ arm, then the default is just "arm" with no architecture information, and that should be a valid build target - all the excitement over there is from me calling out "arm" as an invalid architecture when it's really not. But when that's the case, we no longer know what we were built as (other than just "arm") so we use uname to figure it out at upgrade time.

In this case it seems either your uname lies, or the Go compiler's opinion on what constitutes armv6 is incorrect?

No, the uname is correct, however hf (hard float) is optional in ARMv6, but the Go compiler assumes it's implemented (and the official stance is "if you're on ARMv6 without hf, use GOARM=5"), and in most ARMv6 processors the FPU is implemented, but not in all. I know, not funny. Would setting GOARM=5 as an environment variable convice the upgrade process to download the v5 variant?

Gotcha. No, it doesn't take that into account unfortunately, only the uname result. (Although it could, of course...)

I wonder what the performance penalty for integer code (our crypto and hashing etc) is for running armv5 on armv6/7. If it's small enough, I'd be inclined to just build for v5, call it just "arm", and let those for whom the difference matters build it themselves...

I will try to see if I can find that performance test that someone (was it @AudriusButkevicius ?) once wrote and test it on my other, ARMv7 with hf, platform. Or if you have a benchmark suite that tests exactly the things that Syncthing uses, I could use this.

Actually I think that just starting syncthing, going to settings and hitting the link to preview usage stats will do. There's a number in there for sha256 hashing performance in MB/s. That's not the only thing we do, but it's a common bottle neck and representative enough to get a feeling for it I think.

(There's practically no floating point at all done, only things like dividing two byte counts to show the completion percentage when the gui asks for it and things like that.)

Hmm, that number is very inconsistent. I got it as high as 8.05 on all three builds, but somehow on the GOARM=5 build is scores often much lower than that, sometimes in the 5-6MB/s. But that might be coincidence,  it also just had 6.something on the ARMv7 build. Maybe there's a slight penalty with regards to how many registers are being used, but I'd say it looks like there's little difference between the builds in pure maximum performance. There might be in multi-core performance, but that's hard to tell.
I assume ARM5 on a modern phone will be quite bad?

What makes you think so? When I last checked, there was still no assembler 
version of SHA256 in Go, and even if, would it use NEON or any of the 
opcodes only available in ARMv7? The major advantages of the newer cores 
are rather out-of-order pipelines and more/faster caches and more MHz?!
I am making a wild guess. Though I am sure there will be people screaming for specific builds for their version or ARMv7, atleast I would.

Ok, tested this on a MSM8260A dual-core, 1.5GHz Qualcomm Krait CPU. No difference. Overall performance is about twice as fast as the other platform I tested.
Scores are between 15 and 18 MB/s, where ARMv5 incidentially reported the highest score.
I don't know if this has to do with the random number pool rather than the CPU performance, but in both tests the certificate generation was A LOT slower with the ARMv6 variant, took almost twice as long as v5 or v7!?

So, I think this is a relevant test. Looking at the actual sha256 implementation in the stdlib, it's written in assembler for 386 and amd64 but the other architectures get the Go implementation. Reading around a little it seems the differences aren't too great so I'm going to take a wild guess that we don't lose too much by keeping to armv5 in all cases.

This would only be for the binaries here of course, if someone is deploying on a phone they'll probably have a wrapper and packaging and stuff, and then they can compile as they please for that architecture specifically.

I'm fine with that.. [This page](https://golang.org/doc/install/source#environment) seems to suggest that floating point operations is the only thing that is different with different GOARM settings, so this would be quite irrelevant to Syncthing. Feel free to prove me wrong :)
Oh, one last question (coming back to topic): will auto-upgrade find the new "only arm" version?
Nope, as noted in the pull request we need to publish the armv5/6/7 packages as well at least one or two more releases.
